id_table_1.caption: Departments distribution of the collected medical records.
table: Department # Surgery 180 Internal Medicine 153 Obstetrics and Gynecology 94 Pediatrics 29 Otorhinolaryngology 23 Others 27
references: We collect Chinese medical records across diverse departments online                  2                                    2                         2                         https://bingli.iiyi.com/                               and engage professional physicians for a thorough review. Subsequent to the exclusion of records with deficiencies, such as incomplete information, a total of 506 cases remained. The detailed distribution of these cases among the various departments is presented in Table                  1                . To verify the quality of the collected medical records, we select samples from 10 secondary departments, randomly choosing five cases per department for review. Doctors from corresponding departments are hired to evaluate the “Diagnosis and Treatment” including diagnostic results, diagnostic rationales, and treatment course with a binary choice: either “fundamentally correct” or “obviously incorrect”. If three sections of a medical record are fundamentally accurate, then we consider the medical record to be correct. Overall, expert validation conclude that 94% of the records are deemed as correct.

id_table_2.caption: MVME: GPT-4 evaluation with reference in clinical consultation. GPT-4in One-Step is the upper bound.
table: Symptom Medical Diagnostic Diagnostic Treatment Examination Results Rationales Plan Interaction Baichuan (13B) 2.577 (0.083) 1.632 (0.085) 1.585 (0.081) 1.522 (0.077) 1.419 (0.071) HuatuoGPT-II (13B) 2.832 (0.065) 1.733 (0.075) 1.601 (0.075) 1.601 (0.071) 1.427 (0.065) HuatuoGPT-II (34B) 3.053 (0.055) 1.909 (0.083) 1.756 (0.075) 1.824 (0.077) 1.640 (0.071) GPT-3.5 2.992 (0.040) 1.931 (0.089) 1.717 (0.073) 1.733 (0.073) 1.532 (0.065) Wenxin-4.0 3.034 (0.040) 1.913 (0.081) 1.787 (0.079) 1.794 (0.077) 1.660 (0.073) Qwen-Max 2.851 (0.063) 1.798 (0.079) 1.794 (0.079) 1.863 (0.079) 1.747 (0.073) GPT-4 3.071 (0.038) 1.753 (0.079) 1.881 (0.077) 1.923 (0.077) 1.808 (0.079) Collaboration 2 Doctors w/o DR 3.265 (0.061) 2.291 (0.091) 2.067 (0.085) 2.156 (0.083) 1.972 (0.079) 2 Doctors 3.342 (0.055) 2.413 (0.089) 2.142 (0.083) 2.247 (0.083) 2.077 (0.079) 3 Doctors 3.408 (0.054) 2.489 (0.085) 2.188 (0.084) 2.327 (0.083) 2.118 (0.079) One-Step GPT-4 ∗ - - 2.767 ​ ( 0.049 ) 2.767 0.049 2.767\ (0.049) 2.998 ​ ( 0.040 ) 2.998 0.040 2.998\ (0.040) 2.595 ​ ( 0.055 ) 2.595 0.055 2.595\ (0.055)
references: The primary results are presented in Table                  2                and Table                  3                , and we can infer the following.          (1) One-Step diagnosis significantly surpasses LLMs in interactive consultations, highlighting their limitations in interactions, particularly in eliciting symptoms and medical test results. It also indicates substantial room for improvement in strategies for proactive consultation.          (2) The collaborative use of models can exceed the performance of GPT-4, thereby validating the efficacy of the cooperative mechanism.          (3) Collaboration among “3 Doctors” enhances diagnosis compared to “2 Doctors”, highlighting the benefits of more agents in cooperation.          (4) The removal of the “Dispute Resolution” mechanism from the “2 Doctors” reduces its effectiveness, emphasizing the significance of establishing a better consensus.

id_table_4.caption: Human evaluation for patient and examiner behavior in interactive consultation. Rel, Con and Acc are short for Relevance, Consistency and Accuracy.
table: #QA Rel Con #Test Acc Qwen-Max 429 100.0% 99.0% 56 98.2% Wenxin-4.0 472 100.0% 98.1% 68 98.5% GPT-3.5 417 100.0% 99.5% 57 98.2% GPT-4 378 100.0% 99.7% 61 100.0%
references: We randomly select 50 dialogues from interactive consultations involving GPT-3.5, GPT-4, Wenxin-4.0, and Qwen-Max, resulting in total 200 instances for comprehensive evaluation. We manually annotate each utterance during the evaluation process. The results, presented in Table                  4                , demonstrate high performance (over 98.0%) across all metrics of reliability with respect to patient and examiner interactions, regardless of the intern doctors powered by different LLMs. This highlights the efficacy of our interactive consultation system.
